title: What is the system of government outlined by Plato and Aristotle? - Quora

response.answer_text: Difficult to better Brian’s answer except to suggest that both Plato and Aristotle being ‘post’ rather than pre-Socratics were ‘conditioned’ to move towards considering conclusions which they found ‘agreeable’ and then slide off in that direction without overly considering any objections to it. P:lato’s asymetric theory of forms being a case in point. The mulling over and consideration of ‘ideas’ is what most people consider philosophy to be about. The pre-Socratics e.g. Democritus and others, considered philosophy to be part of ‘science’ hence queried almost everything. For such as Russell this WAS philosophy. In fact Russell went further citing Plato et al as committing tbe ‘worst of philosophic sins’. This aspect of Plato et al seems ill-considered by society at large especially when one considers that with the emergence of the Christian church which obviously considered the Platonists as more ‘user friendly’ for their purposes eventually ushered in the ‘dark ages’ which lasted essentially til the Rennaisance. A criticism of mammoth importance not generally considered by society at large.

response.answer_text: Plato and Aristotle did not agree too much, for the most part, although Aristotle’s respect for Plato as his teacher was considerable. But, in a nutshell: Plato, at heart, believed that the best system of government would be if you could ensure a way for the wise to rule. This inevitably meant some kind of aristocracy (“rule by the best”) and not a democracy. The wisest would somehow be identified (perhaps by the Academy) and then become a small class of philosopher kings. Aristotle may have agreed that such a system might be good in theory, if you could indeed correctly identify who the “wise” were, but he thought that a difficult problem. So Aristotle ended up endorsing democracy, because — and note this carefully — because when it was corrupt (as all systems tend to become), then majority rule does less harm than rule by a corrupt few, which in turn does less harm than rule by a corrupt dictator. Therefore tyranny by the majority isn’t good (according to Aristotle) but tyranny by the few, or the one, is even worse. So, Aristotle gave a kind of back-handed compliment to democracy, essentially saying all systems tend toward corruption and that therefore democracy does less harm. But Plato never quite gave up on his hope of having philosopher kings.
